private_information: I am available the entire workday on Monday.
katherine.goal: Participate in a one-hour meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.

private_information: My calendar is wide open the entire workday on Monday.
nicole.goal: Participate in a one-hour meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.

private_information: I have the following busy blocks on Monday: 09:00-10:00, 10:30-11:30, 12:00-15:30, 16:30-17:00.
kevin.goal: Participate in a one-hour meeting on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.

private_information: I audit temporal and causal consistency. I remove bookkeeping shortcuts and flag ambiguous availability statements.
scheduler_auditor.goal: Validate and clean participant availability reports to ensure temporal consistency and remove shortcuts or post-hoc fixes.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate availability reports and produce a final PDDL domain and problem targeted to FastDownwards that finds a feasible one-hour meeting time for all participants.

public_information: Schedule a one-hour meeting for Katherine, Nicole and Kevin on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.
Work hours are 09:00 to 17:00 on Monday.
There exists at least one solution that fits everyone's existing schedule.

analyze.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar assistant. Extract and publish your available time windows for the target day in a concise machine-readable format. Do not emit PDDL.
analyze.prompt: Your name is katherine. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->katherine->private_information}. Global goal: {agents->katherine->goal}. Produce your availability intervals for the day as a list of strings like ["09:00-17:00"].

analyze.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar assistant. Extract and publish your available time windows for the target day in a concise machine-readable format. Do not emit PDDL.
analyze.prompt: Your name is nicole. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->nicole->private_information}. Global goal: {agents->nicole->goal}. Produce your availability intervals for the day as a list of strings like ["09:00-17:00"].

analyze.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar assistant. Parse your busy blocks and output your free availability windows for the target day in a concise machine-readable format. Do not emit PDDL.
analyze.prompt: Your name is kevin. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Private information: {agents->kevin->private_information}. Global goal: {agents->kevin->goal}. Produce your availability intervals for the day as a list of strings like ["10:00-10:30","11:30-12:00","15:30-16:30"].

audit.system_prompt: You are an auditor specialized in temporal and causal consistency of schedule reports. Your job is to remove bookkeeping shortcuts, detect and resolve ambiguities and overlaps, and provide a cleaned consolidated availability report. Do not emit PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is scheduler_auditor. You receive availability reports: {avail_katherine}, {avail_nicole}, {avail_kevin}. Ensure intervals are consistent with participant private schedules, remove any shortcuts or post-hoc edits, reconcile overlaps and edge cases, and output a cleaned combined availability representation and a short rationale.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert at generating PDDL domains and problems for the FastDownwards solver. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that encode finding a feasible start time for a one-hour meeting given the cleaned availability. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>. Target FastDownwards, include temporal constraints, represent meeting duration explicitly, and prefer earlier start times.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Inputs: {avail_katherine}, {avail_nicole}, {avail_kevin}, {audit_report}. The meeting duration is 60 minutes between 09:00 and 17:00 on Monday. Integrate the cleaned availabilities and produce a PDDL domain and problem that FastDownwards can solve to find a feasible meeting start time. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem>. Keep actions associated with participants distinct where relevant.
